answers.answer: The reason you didn't know about B12 and weightloss before seeing it here is that you evidently have been dealing with competent and honest doctors. If your levels are normal, you don't need it. It's true that the surgery you had MIGHT have led to lower levels, and if it had, that injections might be indicated. But, as is true for most people in your situation, your levels are normal. Normal is normal. You don't need it. And if you did, it would be for treatment of a particular form of anemia, not for weight control.

Surgeon is pretty much correct in his advice BUT any good doctor will tell you that medicine is not an exact science.  What is generally "normall" for the majority does have exceptions for some of us.  I recently became an exception to the rule.  I was experiencing tingling in the hands and feet.  I couldn't sleep. I had no energy. I had sharp pains in my feet and hands.  My balance was getting worse by the day.  I began falling at least once a day.  All tests inclucding blood work came back within the normal ranges.  My primary physician said it's time for a specialist.  I was sent to a neurologist.  He did the same blood tests.  He told me my B12 was too low.  My primary physician said it was at the low in of normal, but still in within the normal ranges.  My neurologist said what is normal for most is not normal for all.  Give her B12 shots.  I have had 2 shots. The tingling and pain slowly subsided over the next 24 to 36 hours.  I sleep much better.  I have had no more problems with balance.  My energy has greatly improved.  I did not experience this great high of energy after ther shot.  If you do not improve - press your doctor for more help.  It may take a speacialist.

question: Hi.  I found this site through a search for B12 shots.  I had an RNY in 2002.  It was very successful. No longer need Diabetes meds, high blood pressure meds, cholesterol, arthritis etc, and lost 160 lbs.  However I did develop anemia in 2004. I had an Iron transfusion in Jan. 2005.  The hematologist diagnosed me with having iron deficient anemia due to poor absorption.  My iron levels and RBC's have been high, 14+ since the infusion.  However the fatigue hangs on, the nerves, and the fogginess, forgetfullness, also still on.  Not much energy to do normal things.  I have blood levels checked every few months.  And B12 is always ok.  I eat a B12 pill sublingual everyday.  My question is, can someone with a gastric bypass eat b12 and have it show up sufficient in bloodwork, and yet, not be utilizing it to be dispersed through the body and provide the essentials to function RBC's, nerves, etc?  I know pernicious anemia is caused by B12 deficiency, but my bloodwork says my levels are fine and I am not deficient.  OF COURSE I have talked to my WLS and primary physican about this and they both say, well your levels are fine.  You do not need B12 shots.  Arrgghh, what is the harm in just trying the shot and see if I feel different?   The docs here act asthough one is asking for CRACK when they ask for a B12 shot.  lol  Until I came ot this site today, I did not know that B12is credited with weight loss!!  interesting.  ANy help is appreciated.  A doc who might recommend B12 to me would be appreciated.  THanks, Jenny
title: B12 Shots after WLS
